title: Safe, Secure, and Trustworthy Development and Use of Artificial Intelligence
summary: Establishes new standards for AI safety and security while protecting Americans' privacy, advancing equity, and protecting workers' rights.
full_text: Establishes new standards for AI safety and security while protecting Americans' privacy, advancing equity, and protecting workers' rights.
plain_language_summary:
Executive Order on Responsible AI Development and Use

Overview: This order aims to ensure AI technologies are developed and used in a safe, secure, and trustworthy manner. It establishes new standards around AI safety, security, privacy, equity, and worker protections.

Bottom Line: Higher education institutions involved in AI research and development will need to review practices for alignment with these new standards.

Key Impacts on Higher Education:

Research: New safety and security requirements may affect AI research projects and funding.

Technology Transfer: Commercialization of AI technologies developed at universities will need to meet new standards.

Data Governance: Increased focus on privacy may require changes to data collection and use policies.

Important Dates:

  • TBD: Specific deadlines for agencies to develop plans and guidance

Affected Departments:

Research Administration, Technology Transfer Office, IT/Data Governance, Legal Affairs

Action Plan:

Action Required: Yes - Universities should review the order and assess implications for their AI programs and policies.

Immediate Steps (0-30 days):

  • Designate point person to lead institutional response
  • Inform key stakeholders of the order
  • Schedule meeting to discuss initial assessment

Short-term Actions (1-3 months):

  • Conduct detailed analysis of institutional AI activities
  • Identify areas requiring policy or practice changes

Long-term Considerations:

  • Proactively shape internal AI governance framework
  • Engage with policymakers on evolving AI standards

Resource Requirements:

Personnel: May require additional compliance and policy staff

Budget: Potential increased compliance and legal costs

Technology: Enhanced security and data protection infrastructure

External Expertise: Engage outside experts to assess technical standards
executive_brief:
Executive Brief

President Biden issued an executive order establishing new standards for AI safety, security, privacy protection, equity, and worker rights that may impact technology development and use at universities.
comprehensive_analysis:
Establishing a Framework for Responsible AI Development and Use

Overview: This executive order seeks to proactively address the risks and societal implications of artificial intelligence as the technologies rapidly advance. It lays out a whole-of-government approach to ensure AI is developed and used in a safe, secure and trustworthy manner, with a focus on protecting privacy, promoting equity, and safeguarding workers.

Bottom Line: Universities are at the forefront of AI research and development. This order establishes new expectations and standards that institutions will need to carefully examine and integrate into their research, technology transfer, and data governance activities.

Policy Context:

Policy Background:

This order builds on prior U.S. AI initiatives like the National AI R&D Strategic Plan and recommendations from the National Security Commission on AI. It elevates AI to a top-level national priority.

Legal Framework:

Specific legal authorities and enforcement mechanisms are not yet clear. The order directs agencies to consider regulatory actions under existing laws. Universities will need to watch for new compliance requirements.

Higher Education Context:

The U.S. higher education sector is a global leader in AI research. This order seeks to maintain that leadership position while ensuring academic AI development aligns with societal values and protections.

Key Impacts on Higher Education:

Research Administration: New AI safety and security requirements may add compliance obligations for research projects and affect federal funding eligibility. Grants and contracts may face increased scrutiny.

Technology Transfer and Commercialization: AI technologies developed at universities will need to meet new standards before being licensed or spun off into startups. This could slow commercialization timelines.

Data Governance and Privacy: As a major source of the data used to train AI, universities will face pressure to strengthen privacy protections and ethical data practices. Data sharing with companies may be restricted.

AI Ethics and Policy: Universities will be expected to contribute to multistakeholder efforts to develop AI governance frameworks. There may be opportunities to shape policy through academic expertise.

Workforce and Education: An emphasis on protecting workers from AI-driven displacement may spur demand for AI education and reskilling programs. Universities should prepare to translate AI research into educational offerings.

Important Dates:

  • 90 days: Agencies submit plans to implement the order
  • 180 days: NIST to develop AI risk management framework
  • 1 year: Agencies report on AI use and impacts
  • Ongoing: Public engagement on AI policy development

Affected Departments:

President/Provost, Research Administration, Technology Transfer Office, IT and Data Governance, Legal Affairs, Ethics and Compliance, Government Affairs, Workforce Development

Implementation Details:

Compliance Requirements:

Universities will need to map the evolving AI standards to institutional policies and procedures. This includes research integrity, human subjects protection, data management, export controls, intellectual property, and socially responsible licensing.

Technical Analysis:

The order emphasizes privacy-preserving AI techniques like federated learning and encrypted computation. Universities will need to build expertise in privacy-enhancing technologies. Technical security standards for AI will require investment.

Cross-Functional Impacts:

While research and technology transfer are most directly impacted, this order has implications university-wide. From data governance to workforce education to public engagement, a coordinated approach will be essential.

Risk Analysis:

Key risks include: Compliance gaps in existing practices, loss of funding for non-conforming research, liability from AI deployments, reputational damage from irresponsible AI, inability to attract top AI talent.

Strategic Considerations:

Competitive Implications:

Universities that proactively align with these AI principles may have an advantage in federal funding, industry partnerships, and faculty and student recruitment. However, some researchers may feel constrained by new oversight.

Long-term Vision:

This order accelerates the integration of social responsibility into the AI innovation ecosystem. Universities are positioned to lead in developing the next generation of AI talent and shaping the future of trustworthy AI.

Advocacy Opportunities:

Universities should actively engage as the AI standards and governance frameworks are developed. There are opportunities to translate academic expertise into policy influence and shape the implementation of the order.

Action Plan:

Action Required: Yes - The wide-reaching nature of this order necessitates a coordinated institutional response. Universities must thoroughly assess their AI activities, identify risk areas, and proactively develop governance strategies.

Immediate Steps (0-30 days):

  • Brief senior leadership on the order and its implications
  • Designate an AI policy coordinator to lead institutional response
  • Catalog all AI research projects, funding, and commercial activities
  • Review data governance and security practices related to AI

Short-term Actions (1-3 months):

  • Conduct risk assessment of AI activities based on new standards
  • Develop institutional AI principles and governance framework
  • Update research and commercialization policies and procedures
  • Educate faculty, staff and students on responsible AI practices

Long-term Considerations:

  • Establish ongoing monitoring for AI policy developments
  • Actively contribute to development of AI standards and best practices
  • Build cross-disciplinary responsible AI education and training

Resource Requirements:

Personnel: Dedicated AI policy staff, cross-functional AI governance committees, enhanced compliance capabilities

Budget: Investments in technical infrastructure, policy development, training and education, potential increases in compliance and legal spending

Technology: Tools for AI inventory and risk assessment, secure computing environments, privacy-enhancing technologies

External Expertise: Engage legal, ethics, and technical standards experts to help shape institutional approach and contribute to AI policy discussions
